MN

•-••

VOL. LXXIV, NO. 5A

74th YEAR

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MARYLAND, October 16, 1969

M-Day:Thousands March from J.H.U.,
Non-Violence Prevails Across Nation

In Washington
Special to the News-Letter

WASHINGTON—Activity in
'Washington yesterday was low-key
despite the wide range of activities
and demonstrations and the
thousands of people who entered
the capital for moratorium day.
More than thirty organized
protests took place around the
Washington area, ranging from
satirical dramatic presentations on
the steps of the Capitol to a
massive protest march which
began at the Sylvan Theater (in
the shadow of the Washington
Monument) and travelled to the
White House. As in most cities

throughout the country,
individual demonstrations were
held throughout the day by the
students on various campuses, and
only late in the afternoon did all
supporters join for a "mass
protest."
50,000 Candles
The "mass protest" took the
form of a candlelight march on
the White House. Starting from
the Washington Monument, the
demonstrators,each of Mom held a
lighted candle signifying one life
lost in VietNam, proceeded to the
White House gates. There, the
candles were extinguished.
(continued to page 2)

At Hopkins
Special to the News-Letter

HOMEWOOD—A crowd which
grew from 700 to 6,000 flowed
through Homewood campus
yesterday to support the
nationwide student boycott called
to protest America's presence in
Viet Nam.
About seven hundred students,
with a scattering of adults,
participated in the anti-war
activities at Hopkins during most
of the day before busloads of high
school and local college students
converged on the campus at 4
p.m.
The protestors, then about

pics by hoffinatin
upper pic by hill

6,000 strong, marched down
Maryland Avenue to a rally held at
Charles Center. Later last night, a
candle light service for Hopkins'
war dead and a folk mass were
held on campus, and attended by
about 250 people.
The moritorium activities were
peaceful here as elsewhere in
Baltimore except for verbal
threats voiced by about thirty
students at an Academic Council
meeting late yesterday afternoon.
Although there was talk of
"busting up" the closed-door
Council meeting, no action was
taken.
(continued to page 4)

PAGE 2

NEWS LETTER

October 16, 1969

Over 50,000 Demonstrate In D.C.
(continued from page 1)

Before leaving the Sylvan
Theater area (just South of the
monument), the marchers were
addressed by Mrs. Corretta King
and Reverend Channing Phillips.
The huge crowd overflowed the
Sylvan Theater area making
estimates of its size difficult. It is
generally agreed, however, that
more than 50,000 demonstrators
were present.
McCarthy and McGovern
Other• highlights of the day
included speeches by Eugene
McCarthy and George McGovern.
McCarthy expressed sympathy for
the moratorium in a brief speech
and stated that those present must
continue the work which began
with the primaries of 1968.
McGovern also expressed
complete support for the
protesters. He argued for U.S.
withdrawl on both moral and
pragmatic grounds, saying that the
protestors were displaying a
"higher kind of patriotism" by
questioning those policies which
they thought wrong.
Dr. Benjamin Spock addressed
a rally in the courtyard of the
George Washington University
Law School. Before one to two
thousand applauding
demonstrators, Spock said that he
detested agression in any
form—"whether it be communist
agression, royalist agression, or
democratic capitalistic agression."

"!

„

t.'777;.(40:6•'%"., •

The entire day of protest in
Washington was marked by a lack
of friction and "tactics of
confrontation." Even where
counterdemonstrators drew up
picket lines in opposition to the
moratorium, the atmosphere
remained generally calm.

*
,;:ei

Organizers at SAIS felt that
this placid atmosphere was a point
in favor of the moratorium. The
literature handed out was
conspicuously more reasoned and
less emotional than the pamphlets
and flyers handed out at other
protest actions.
Outside of the campuses and
major centers of demonstration
activity, little seemed to be altered
in Washington. On the streets of
Washington's business district
opinions were varied considering
the propriety of the moratorium.
One lady (wearing red, white and
blue) said that the "dirty children
ought to be shot." However,
organizers were encouraged to see
numerous buttons and armbands
displayed on business suits. It is
generally felt that if a two day
halt is called in November,
supporters can expect much
greater cooperation from business
and industry.
SAIS Programs
In the morning hours, the focus
of activity was the School for
Advanced International Studies.
SAIS was the school most
successful in extending its
resources and influence off of its
own campus.
Beginning at 10:00 a.m. SAIS
presented a "teach-in" in its main
administration building. Marcus
Raskin, formerly an organizer in
the McCarthy campaign, Lester
Gelb, a senior fellow at the
Brookings Institution, and Herbert
Dinerstein, Professor of Soviet
Studies at SAIS delivered lectures
to the crowd of nearly 150 people
which assembled. The three
speakers discused the arguments
for withdraw! from VietNam, with
Raskin concentrating more heavily
on the tactic of moratorium and
what individuals could do to stop
the war.
Richard Sobrine, one of the
key organizers of the SAIS
activities said he was encouraged
by the number of outsiders who
came to SA1S for the teach-in.
"We opened this up to anybody
who wanted to come and a lot of
Brookings people came," said
Sobrine. He stated that attendance
would have been considerably
higher if the SAIS people had not
been engagedin other activities.

•
pic by hoffinom
Dr. Benjamin Spock addresses assemblage at George Washington University.

streets and do something—these
kids are in a state of rebellion
anyway." The lecture program, he
stated, would ensure that the high
school students know exactly why
they are in the streets before they
actually are asked to demonstrate.
All of the organizers at SAIS
felt it important that they not
confine their activities to their
immediate area. "Look at it this
way," said one,"everyone at SAIS
knows the issues on VietNam. He
may have an opinion which
doesn't agree with the
moratorium, but you can be sure
that he knows the issues and has
formed an opinion."

SAIS students felt that their
numbers would have been
significantly increased had
members of the student body and
faculty not felt constrained by
their ties with the State
Department. Miss Dahn stated
that "a fairly good number" of
students and faculty worked for
the State Department. Sobrine
cited one professor who works for
the Department of Defense
wanting to participate in the
Teach-in. "I'd like to sit in, even
representing our (the Defense
Department's) point of view,but I
dare' not," 'the faculty member
stated.

111

8Ii
•

t

4;•.,

k

High School Lectures

•

Specifically, 35 SAIS students
were lecturing at area high
schools. Tamara Dahn, another
student who was instrumental in
organizing the school's
moratorium activities, stated that
the high school lectures were the
most important part of SAIS'
program. Sobrine also considered
the high school program the most
important facet of the day's
activity. "One thing is for sure,"
said Sobrine. "The high school
students are more radicalized than
most of the universities. The high
school kids want to get out on the
pic by hoffmann

PAGE 3

NEWS -LETTER

October 16, 1969

"Let's Get Together"—Baltimore Moratorium
Speical to the News-Leter
BALTIMORE—Although vocal
disharmony overcame the singers,
the song "Let's Get Together"
summed up the noon and evening
rallies at Charles Center yesterday,
attended by 7,000 peaceful
demonstrators in the afternoon,
and 11,000 last night.
There were all types: black and
White, young and old, with bells
and suits or minis and
knee-huggers. Placards displayed
their unity: "Leave
VietNam—Fight For Peace and
Justice Here," "Medical Students
For • Peace," "Maryland Veterans
For Peace."
At 4:30 p.m. yesterday about
7,000 marchers left the
Homewood campus in route to
the Federal Plaza in Charles
Center where they were met by
4,000 additional demonstrators.
"Dying In Vain"
The keynote speaker of the
evening rally was former Alaskan
Senator Ernest Gruening. He told
the crowd that "today's
demonstrations were just the
beginning," and lashed out at the
Present and past administrations'
handling of the war. Calling
himself an "all-out opponent of

but they were hardly hostile.
Murmurs from the sidewalks
included a number of "God Bless
You's" and a wisecrack, "If you
want peace, go down to the
block."
Earlier yesterday, construction
workers at a nearby building
occasionally booed the speakers.
There were about twenty-five
hecklers last night.
Besides Gruening, speakers at
the evening rally included Ed Cox
of GI's United to Bring the War
Home, Zeke Boyd of the Black
Labor Alliance, Dee Ann Papas of
the Women's Liberation
Movement and Irving Beinin of
the National Mobilization
Committee to End the War in
VietNam.
Solidarity
The noon rally began with five
minutes of silence after folk tunes
including "This Land Is Your
Land" and "Let's Get Together"
were sung by college-age students.
Although in both demonstrations,
college students were
predominant, there were many
over-thirty in the audience
Especially during the downtown
'rallies, there was a feeling of ease
and solidarity *among the .vapious
age and color groups.
All the demonstrations
yesterday in Baltimore were
peaceful, Governor Mandel
ordered 800 National Guards on
alert, while the Baltimore police
force was noticeably beefed up. A
large. detail of policemen armed
with riot helmets patrolled the
plaza with reserves ready nearby.
Several plain clothes agents
mingled with the crowd. A police
official stated late yesterday
afternoon that if there would be
any violence, it would probably

pic by anderson

come from anti-moritorium
groups.
The main speakers at the noon
rally were Senator Joseph Tyding
of Maryland, Mrs. Martin Luther
King, Jr. Vice-mayor Jacob
Edelman, and Lawrence Cardinal
Sheehan, Archbishop of
Baltimore.
,

pic by anderson

our folly," Gruening stated that
the soldiers in VietNam are "dying
in vain."
"From the beginning, the
American people were misled, lied
to and tricked into this war," the
former senator claimed,"...The
blood of these boys is on their
(the legislature's) hands." He also
criticized the draft system.
"Whether they are made cannon
fodder by a lottery or draft makes
no difference," he said.
Gruening and former Senator
Wayne Morse of Oregon were the
only opponents to the 1965 Gulf
of Tonkin resolution. The former
Alaskan senator was one of the
most adamant early spokesmen
against the VietNam War.
Dummy Coffin
The late afternoon march
down Maryland and Cathedral
Streets from Hopkins, was led by
serveral priests carrying a dummy
coffin. There was little heckling at
the marchers. Most of the
Passersby seemed somewhat
surprised by the demonstrators,

Senator Tydings said that
America "must end the war
because it is right." He claimed
that the war has become a moral
issue, and "it is time to give the
compete truth to the American
people." Mrs. King, unable to
attend the rally in person due to
the death of a close friend,
reinforced her husband's position
on the immediate withdrawal of
American troops in VietNam and
re-emphasized the nature of the
moritorium to "be the conscience
of the American people."
Jacob Edelman represented the
Baltimore city government(Mayor
Thomas D'Alesandro, though he
has previously expressed his
opposition to the VietNam War,
was in New York yesterday
Series.)
watching the World
Stated Edelman, "The voice of
this moratorium should be heard
by the industrial-military complex
of this nation—and, yes, even Mr.
Nixon."
Archbishop Sheehan called for a
"speedy and honorable end of
th_e war and a true and just peace
based on the common good."
Earlier yesterday, Baltimore
comptroller, Hyman A. Pressman
held a counter demonstration in
front of City Hall. A group of
about forty veterans assembled to
salute the American flag. "It is
important that it be made clear
why we are here today," Pressman
stated to the group."You are here
because you love your country
and your country's flag."

PAGE 4

NEWS—LETTER

October 16, 1969

Hopkins' Lack of Activism Attacked
(Continued from page 1)

Although Hopkins refused to
officially recognize the
moritorium, most classes were
shut down. Dr. Chester Wickwire,
Chaplain of the University noted
that 40 of the 52 classes scheduled
between 9 and 11 a.m. Wednesday
morning were cancelled, and those
professors holding class faced a
primarily empty classroom.
Dr. Richard Pfeffer, professor
of political science, said "I respect
the sincerity of their decision (not
to cancel classes for the
Moratorium) but I don't respect
their intelligence."
Other speakers took exception
to the general lack of activism on
the Hopkins campus. John Guess,
president of the Student Council
stated "When was the last time
before the Moratorium that you
heard about Viet Nam in the
classroom? What kind of a
University is this?"

pic by anderson

Dr. Richard Pfeffer

Both Pfeffer and Rev. Vernon
Dobson felt that those assembled
at Keyser Quadrangle were "just
out there for the sun."
"As I look at this group I'm
not sure that we're getting

across," Dobson said.
Dr. Wickwire, while basically
agreeing that the campus is
fundamentally a quiet campus,
noted the large amount of people
expressing interest in the Viet Nam
Moratorium. "I'm encouraged by
the number of people who turned
out," he continued, "The
important thing is that they're
there—their presence indicates a
concern."
Late in the _ afternoon, the
crowd surrounding the Gilman
Hall stage had overflowed into the
surrounding areas.
Just Twenty
Larry Goldberg, president of
the Ad Hoc Committee on the
Vietnam Moratorium, then
announced that the Academic
Council was meeting in Shriver
Hall. He suggested that "twenty of
you" march into Shriver and
attempt to stop the meeting, but a
large crowd moved into Shriver
Hall, collecting outside of the
closed Board Room to chant
"Peace Now, Peace Now."
John Guess appeared and
attempted to restore calm. "We're
going into the meeting to request
that they do not meet. If they
refuse, We've come too far to turn
back now. All we can do is make
enough noise so they can't get any
work done." Bilgrave was then
"asked" to request that the
Council open the meeting to
students.
The Council allowed Guess to
speak for ten minutes and then
stated that any Council member
who did not wish to participate
was under no compulsion to do
so. He noted that if a quorum was
reached, the meeting would be
held as usual.
Only two professors left the
meeting: Drs. Carl Swanson and
Robert Strider. Drs. Michael Beer
and Aihud Pevsner refused to
enter the meeting, contending that

450

yp<

,

•

-4
pic by !own

pic by hoffmann

the Council had the right to meet.
Dr. Swanson stated that he
would not attend a meeting
"behind closed doors."
"I have the right to be here
(outside the Academic Council
meeting)," commented Pevsner,
"but they have the right to be in
there."
Pfeffer countered by saying
that "The whole spirit of the
Moratorium was that we wanted
to repress the war. We can do this
peacefully by making a
disturbance outside the room."
Jim Archibald, President of the
Student Association, presently
faces the threat of expulsion due
to his part in the hiring of a
rock-and-roll band for the
teach-in. The band, hired by Dr.
Wickwire, was originally supposed
to play only for seven minutes.
Dr. Allyn Kimbal, Dean of
Faculty of Arts and Sciences,
however, refused Archibald
permission for the band to play.
He argued that this would result in
"disturbance of the University."
Archibald immediately, hired the
band for a total of five hours, or
as often as the program would
allow.
The Administration is presently
examining the possible alternatives
for response to Archibald's
actions.
There is presently a petition
circulating on campus stating that
the 100 plus signers "take equal
responsibility" for the presence of

the band. The Administration has
not commented.
Despite the varied responses on
the campus to the Moratorium,
the majority of the speakers
addressed themselves to policy
questions in Viet Nam. Pfeffer
noted that being anti-war was
presently acceptable to the
American people, but that the
concept of unilateral withdrawl
remained unacceptable
"But a dishonorable peace is all
we can get and all we deserve," he
said. "We treat 'national interest'
as if someone who had lost their
virginity could repaste themselves
together." We have to face the
national dishonor and the real
defeat."
Paul Lauter, national head of
Resist, offered another perspective
on the war. "Our actions is to give
support to the NLF. Agnew is
wrong when he says we are giving
aid and support to our enemies
because the NLF aren't the
enemy."
"We are supporting the
Vietnamese Revolution," he
further commented.
After those students
demonstrating outside the
Academic Council meeting had
returned to the Keyser Quad., the
majority of those present felt the
upper campus and marched
around the school. From the
cam pus they marched down
Maryland Avenue to the
downtown rallies.

with riot helmets patrolled the
plaza with reserves ready nearby.
Several plain clothes agents
mingled with the crowd. A police
official stated late yesterday
afternoon that if there would be
any violence, it would probably

pic by anderson

come from anti-moritorium
groups.
The main speakers at the noon
rally were Senator Joseph Tyding
of Maryland, Mrs. Martin Luther
King, Jr. Vice-mayor Jacob
Edelman, and Lawrence Cardinal
Sheehan, Archbishop of
Baltimore.
,

pic by anderson

our folly," Gruening stated that
the soldiers in VietNam are "dying
in vain."
"From the beginning, the
American people were misled, lied
to and tricked into this war," the
former senator claimed,"...The
blood of these boys is on their
(the legislature's) hands." He also
criticized the draft system.
"Whether they are made cannon
fodder by a lottery or draft makes
no difference," he said.
Gruening and former Senator
Wayne Morse of Oregon were the
only opponents to the 1965 Gulf
of Tonkin resolution. The former
Alaskan senator was one of the
most adamant early spokesmen
against the VietNam War.
Dummy Coffin
The late afternoon march
down Maryland and Cathedral
Streets from Hopkins, was led by
serveral priests carrying a dummy
coffin. There was little heckling at
the marchers. Most of the
Passersby seemed somewhat
surprised by the demonstrators,

Senator Tydings said that
America "must end the war
because it is right." He claimed
that the war has become a moral
issue, and "it is time to give the
compete truth to the American
people." Mrs. King, unable to
attend the rally in person due to
the death of a close friend,
reinforced her husband's position
on the immediate withdrawal of
American troops in VietNam and
re-emphasized the nature of the
moritorium to "be the conscience
of the American people."
Jacob Edelman represented the
Baltimore city government(Mayor
Thomas D'Alesandro, though he
has previously expressed his
opposition to the VietNam War,
was in New York yesterday
Series.)
watching the World
Stated Edelman, "The voice of
this moratorium should be heard
by the industrial-military complex
of this nation—and, yes, even Mr.
Nixon."
Archbishop Sheehan called for a
"speedy and honorable end of
th_e war and a true and just peace
based on the common good."
Earlier yesterday, Baltimore
comptroller, Hyman A. Pressman
held a counter demonstration in
front of City Hall. A group of
about forty veterans assembled to
salute the American flag. "It is
important that it be made clear
why we are here today," Pressman
stated to the group."You are here
because you love your country
and your country's flag."

PAGE 4

NEWS—LETTER

October 16, 1969

Hopkins' Lack of Activism Attacked
(Continued from page 1)

Although Hopkins refused to
officially recognize the
moritorium, most classes were
shut down. Dr. Chester Wickwire,
Chaplain of the University noted
that 40 of the 52 classes scheduled
between 9 and 11 a.m. Wednesday
morning were cancelled, and those
professors holding class faced a
primarily empty classroom.
Dr. Richard Pfeffer, professor
of political science, said "I respect
the sincerity of their decision (not
to cancel classes for the
Moratorium) but I don't respect
their intelligence."
Other speakers took exception
to the general lack of activism on
the Hopkins campus. John Guess,
president of the Student Council
stated "When was the last time
before the Moratorium that you
heard about Viet Nam in the
classroom? What kind of a
University is this?"

pic by anderson

Dr. Richard Pfeffer

Both Pfeffer and Rev. Vernon
Dobson felt that those assembled
at Keyser Quadrangle were "just
out there for the sun."
"As I look at this group I'm
not sure that we're getting

across," Dobson said.
Dr. Wickwire, while basically
agreeing that the campus is
fundamentally a quiet campus,
noted the large amount of people
expressing interest in the Viet Nam
Moratorium. "I'm encouraged by
the number of people who turned
out," he continued, "The
important thing is that they're
there—their presence indicates a
concern."
Late in the _ afternoon, the
crowd surrounding the Gilman
Hall stage had overflowed into the
surrounding areas.
Just Twenty
Larry Goldberg, president of
the Ad Hoc Committee on the
Vietnam Moratorium, then
announced that the Academic
Council was meeting in Shriver
Hall. He suggested that "twenty of
you" march into Shriver and
attempt to stop the meeting, but a
large crowd moved into Shriver
Hall, collecting outside of the
closed Board Room to chant
"Peace Now, Peace Now."
John Guess appeared and
attempted to restore calm. "We're
going into the meeting to request
that they do not meet. If they
refuse, We've come too far to turn
back now. All we can do is make
enough noise so they can't get any
work done." Bilgrave was then
"asked" to request that the
Council open the meeting to
students.
The Council allowed Guess to
speak for ten minutes and then
stated that any Council member
who did not wish to participate
was under no compulsion to do
so. He noted that if a quorum was
reached, the meeting would be
held as usual.
Only two professors left the
meeting: Drs. Carl Swanson and
Robert Strider. Drs. Michael Beer
and Aihud Pevsner refused to
enter the meeting, contending that

pic by !own

pic by hoffmann

the Council had the right to meet.
Dr. Swanson stated that he
would not attend a meeting
"behind closed doors."
"I have the right to be here
(outside the Academic Council
meeting)," commented Pevsner,
"but they have the right to be in
there."
Pfeffer countered by saying
that "The whole spirit of the
Moratorium was that we wanted
to repress the war. We can do this
peacefully by making a
disturbance outside the room."
Jim Archibald, President of the
Student Association, presently
faces the threat of expulsion due
to his part in the hiring of a
rock-and-roll band for the
teach-in. The band, hired by Dr.
Wickwire, was originally supposed
to play only for seven minutes.
Dr. Allyn Kimbal, Dean of
Faculty of Arts and Sciences,
however, refused Archibald
permission for the band to play.
He argued that this would result in
"disturbance of the University."
Archibald immediately, hired the
band for a total of five hours, or
as often as the program would
allow.
The Administration is presently
examining the possible alternatives
for response to Archibald's
actions.
There is presently a petition
circulating on campus stating that
the 100 plus signers "take equal
responsibility" for the presence of

the band. The Administration has
not commented.
Despite the varied responses on
the campus to the Moratorium,
the majority of the speakers
addressed themselves to policy
questions in Viet Nam. Pfeffer
noted that being anti-war was
presently acceptable to the
American people, but that the
concept of unilateral withdrawl
remained unacceptable
"But a dishonorable peace is all
we can get and all we deserve," he
said. "We treat 'national interest'
as if someone who had lost their
virginity could repaste themselves
together." We have to face the
national dishonor and the real
defeat."
Paul Lauter, national head of
Resist, offered another perspective
on the war. "Our actions is to give
support to the NLF. Agnew is
wrong when he says we are giving
aid and support to our enemies
because the NLF aren't the
enemy."
"We are supporting the
Vietnamese Revolution," he
further commented.
After those students
demonstrating outside the
Academic Council meeting had
returned to the Keyser Quad., the
majority of those present felt the
upper campus and marched
around the school. From the
cam pus they marched down
Maryland Avenue to the
downtown rallies.
